Key Highlights for Medical Decision\u201:
• Incomplete medication reconciliation: no documentation of over‑the‑counter or herbal supplements, adherence assessment, or home glucose logs.  
• Lack of standardized depression screening despite self‑reported stress and lifestyle barriers.  
• Absence of comprehensive immunization review and health maintenance planning.  
• Limited risk stratification for ASCVD and CKD progression—no formal calculation of 10‑year risk or staging discussion beyond eGFR.  
• Opportunity to optimize glycemic control by adding evidence‑based agents (SGLT‑2i/GLP‑1 RA) given CKD and high A1c.  
• Underaddressed lifestyle interventions: no structured referral to dietician or exercise program.  
• Preventive screenings (retinopathy, foot exam, colon cancer) not documented as scheduled or completed.  
• Missing follow‑up intervals and contingency triggers (e.g., if A1c >8% after 3 months).  
• Cost‑containment: no discussion of generic statin selection, low‑cost behavioral supports, or prior authorization needs for newer antidiabetic agents.
Chief Concern: Refill of metformin for type 2 diabetes mellitus management.
Assessment: 62‑year‑old male with established type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed 2 years ago, presenting for refill of metformin ER 500 mg BID.  Despite maximal tolerated metformin dose, A1c is 9.8% and he admits to poor adherence (out of meds 6 months), no home glucose monitoring, unbalanced diet, no exercise, and significant psychosocial stress from divorce.  Vital signs notable for BMI 38 kg/m2, BP 130/79. Exam unremarkable; feet exam and monofilament testing normal.  Labs: eGFR 55 mL/min (CKD 3a), urine ACR 50 mg/g (moderately increased albuminuria), LDL 137 mg/dL.  Differential: 1) uncontrolled type 2 DM; 2) obesity‑related insulin resistance; 3) early diabetic kidney disease with albuminuria.

Problem\u00a01.Status: Not at goal (A1c 9.8%) despite metformin ER 2000 mg daily
Problem\u00a01.Decision Making and Diagnositic Plan: Reviewed A1c, eGFR, albuminuria; referred for retinopathy screening.  Will obtain baseline and 3‑month follow‑up labs (A1c, CMP, lipids, urine ACR).  Assess for hypoglycemia and GI tolerance.
Problem\u00a01.Treatment/Medication Plan:
• Continue metformin ER 500 mg BID (generic)  
• Initiate empagliflozin 10 mg daily (renal protection, cardioprotection) given eGFR 55  
• Advise structured SMBG twice daily initially, then PRN.  
• Lifestyle: referral to dietician, prescribe 150 min/week moderate exercise.
Problem\u00a01.Contingency Planning: If A1c remains >8% at 3 months, consider adding dulaglutide 0.75 mg weekly.  If eGFR falls <45, discontinue empagliflozin.  If GI side effects, reduce metformin to 500 mg BID and retitrate.
Problem\u00a01.Considerations for Documentation Improve: Document patient’s adherence history, home glucose values, SMBG teaching and logs, tolerance of metformin, and shared decision‑making regarding new agents.
Problem\u00a01.Considerations for Cost Effective Care I: Use generic metformin, empagliflozin available as generic soon—check formulary.  Utilize manufacturer savings cards for SGLT‑2i.  Leverage free diabetes education programs.

Problem\u00a02.Status: Not at goal; contributing to insulin resistance
Problem\u00a02.Decision Making and Diagnositic Plan: Measured BMI and waist circumference; assessed readiness to change.  Screened for secondary causes (normal TSH on last CMP panel).
Problem\u00a02.Treatment/Medication Plan:
• Referral to outpatient weight management program and dietician.  
• Prescribe home walking program, target 10 000 steps/day gradually.  
• Consider orlistat if <5% weight loss in 3 months and no contraindications.
Problem\u00a02.Contingency Planning: If no weight loss ≥5% at 3 months, discuss pharmacotherapy (orlistat) or weight loss referral.  If bariatric surgery criteria met and lifestyle fails, refer to surgery evaluation.
Problem\u00a02.Considerations for Documentation Improve: Include detailed nutritional assessment, weekly exercise logs, and weight change trajectory.
Problem\u00a02.Considerations for Cost Effective Care I: Promote free community exercise classes, online healthy eating resources; avoid expensive weight loss drugs unless criteria met.

Problem\u00a03.Status: Not at goal; LDL 137 mg/dL (goal <100 mg/dL)
Problem\u00a03.Decision Making and Diagnositic Plan: Confirmed fasting lipid panel; calculated ASCVD 10‑year risk >20%.  No contraindications to statin.
Problem\u00a03.Treatment/Medication Plan: Initiate atorvastatin 40 mg PO nightly (high‑intensity statin).  Counsel on diet (reduce saturated fat).
Problem\u00a03.Contingency Planning: Check LFTs at 6 weeks; if transaminases >3× ULN or myalgias, reduce to 20 mg or switch to rosuvastatin 10 mg.
Problem\u00a03.Considerations for Documentation Improve: Document discussion of ASCVD risk, statin benefits/risks, and patient preference.
Problem\u00a03.Considerations for Cost Effective Care I: Use generic atorvastatin; coordinate prescription with metformin refill to reduce co‑pays.

Problem\u00a04.Problem Name: Chronic kidney disease stage 3a with microalbuminuria
Problem\u00a04.Status: Stage 3a (eGFR 55), ACR 50 mg/g indicates moderate albuminuria
Problem\u00a04.Decision Making and Diagnositic Plan: Monitored CMP, eGFR, ACR.  No referral to nephrology at this stage; will monitor progression.
Problem\u00a04.Treatment/Medication Plan: Start lisinopril 10 mg PO daily to reduce albuminuria (even with BP 130/79).  Monitor creatinine and K in 2 weeks.
Problem\u00a04.Contingency Planning: If serum creatinine rises >30% or potassium >5.5 mmol/L, reduce or hold lisinopril.  If progression (eGFR declines >5 mL/min/year), refer nephrology.
Problem\u00a04.Considerations for Documentation Improve: Record albuminuria staging, rationale for ACEi initiation despite normotension, and monitoring plan.
Problem\u00a04.Considerations for Cost Effective Care I: Generic lisinopril; combine refill pick‑up to lower patient visits.

Problem\u00a05.Status: Not formally assessed; patient endorses low priority of health due to divorce
Problem\u00a05.Decision Making and Diagnositic Plan: Administer PHQ‑9 today; assess social supports and coping.  Screen for anxiety with GAD‑7 if indicated.
Problem\u00a05.Treatment/Medication Plan:
• If PHQ‑9 ≥10, initiate sertraline 50 mg daily.  
• Refer to behavioral health/counseling support.  
• Provide stress management resources (support group).
Problem\u00a05.Contingency Planning: If no improvement in mood or PHQ‑9 score remains ≥10 in 4 weeks, consider therapy intensification or switch to another SSRI.
Problem\u00a05.Considerations for Documentation Improve: Document PHQ‑9 score, social history details, patient resources provided, and follow‑up plan.
Problem\u00a05.Considerations for Cost Effective Care I: Use free or sliding‑scale community mental health services; generic sertraline if indicated.

Anticipatory Preventative Care.Item\u00a01: Annual diabetic eye exam referral (ophthalmology) — evidence shows early retinopathy detection reduces vision loss.
Anticipatory Preventative Care.Item\u00a02: Foot exam at every visit; patient education on daily foot self‑inspection to prevent ulcers.
Anticipatory Preventative Care.Item\u00a03: Immunizations: influenza annually; pneumococcal PCV13 followed by PPSV23; zoster vaccine recombinant (Shingrix); update COVID‑19 boosters per CDC.
Anticipatory Preventative Care.Item\u00a04: Colon cancer screening—colonoscopy if none in past 10 years (age 62).
Anticipatory Preventative Care.Item\u00a05: Lifestyle counseling for tobacco/alcohol (patient is a non‑smoker, counsel on moderate alcohol).
Anticipatory Preventative Care.Item\u00a06: Bone health: screen for osteoporosis if additional risk factors emerge (not indicated now).
Anticipatory Preventative Care.Considerations for Documentation Improve: Create a health maintenance table in the chart with documentation of due/completed items and dates; prompt immunization history intake.

Follow Up Care.Item\u00a01: Recheck HbA1c in 3 months to assess glycemic control and medication efficacy.
Follow Up Care.Item\u00a02: Monitor BMP (including eGFR, electrolytes) and urine ACR in 6 months to track CKD progression.
Follow Up Care.Item\u00a03: Lipid panel in 3 months to evaluate statin response and adjust dose.
Follow Up Care.Item\u00a04: Blood pressure checks at home weekly; review at next visit; assess lisinopril tolerance.
Follow Up Care.Item\u00a05: Weight and BMI at each visit; goal ≥5% weight loss by 3 months.
Follow Up Care.Item\u00a06: PHQ‑9 in 4 weeks to monitor mood and treatment response.
Follow Up Care.Considerations for Documentation Improve: Standardize follow‑up template with pending orders, target dates, and owner for each item; incorporate patient self‑monitoring logs and telehealth check‑ins.
